hawaiian_text: Lālau akula ‘o Puali‘i i ke ko‘ilipi a hele akula ā  hiki i waena ā loa‘a o Nāmakaokapāo‘o e kunu ana  i nā ‘au ‘uala āna ‘ehā, i luna o ke ahi. ‘Ike maila nā  keiki a pau loa, holo akula lākou ā kū maila ma kahi  lō‘ihi no ka maka‘u ia Puali‘i. ‘Ōlelo akula ‘o Puali‘i  iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “‘Ē\! Eia ke ko‘ilipi ma ku‘u  lima, he mea ‘o‘oki no kō po‘o i kēia lā, a moku kō po‘o, a laila, kālua me ka ‘uala, a ‘ai iho a‘u ma mua, a laila, noa.” ‘A‘ohe ho‘olohe mai ‘o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o i kēia mau ‘ōlelo a Puali‘i, a laila,  ‘ōlelo hou ‘o Puali‘i, ‘o ka lua ia. Mākaukau ‘o  Puali‘i e ‘o‘oki ia Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ke ko‘ilipi, i ia  wā i pule ai ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o i kāna pule make  no Puali‘i. Penei ua pule lā:  Aloha wale ka maka o a‘u wahi pāo‘o, E hapupu‘u, e hāpāpa‘a mai nei,  E ‘ai paha, e waiho paha,  E waiho paha Nākukui‘aimakaokalani,  ‘O Kukui‘aimakaokalani kēlā,  ‘O ku‘u wahi aikāne kēia,  ‘O Nāmakaokai‘a ke ali‘i nui o Hawai‘i,  E he‘e lā, e he‘e ka hōhē wale,  ‘O kānaka nō me ka ihe,  ‘O ka ihe nō me ka pahu,  Make nō iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o.
gpt-4_1-mini_translation:
Puali‘i grabbed the machete and went until he reached where Nāmakaokapāo‘o was piercing four sweet potato vines over the fire. All the children saw and ran away, stopping in a distant place because they were afraid of Puali‘i. Puali‘i said to Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “Hey! Here is the machete in my hand, a tool to cut your head today, then your head will be cooked with the sweet potatoes, and I will eat first, then you will be free.” Nāmakaokapāo‘o did not listen to these words of Puali‘i, so Puali‘i spoke a second time. Puali‘i was ready to cut Nāmakaokapāo‘o with the machete when at that moment Nāmakaokapāo‘o prayed his death chant for Puali‘i. It went as follows:  
The eye of my head is only beloved,  
It flinches, it trembles,  
Should it eat, or should it allow,  
Allow Nākukui‘aimakaokalani,  
That is Kukui‘aimakaokalani,  
This is my close companion,  
Nāmakaokai‘a is the great chief of Hawai‘i,  
Let it glide, let the sting glide,  
People with spears,  
The spear with the club,  
Nāmakaokapāo‘o will truly die.
gpt-4_1-mini_commentary:
• **Contextual overview:**  
  – This paragraph portrays a dramatic confrontation between Puali‘i and Nāmakaokapāo‘o amid a tense, symbolic scene involving sweet potato vines and a threatening machete. Puali‘i’s threat to sever Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s head is provocative and evokes themes of mortal conflict and ritual death, while Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s prayer or chant responds with a mix of defiance and invocation of ancestral and divine power.

• **Characters and actions:**  
  – Puali‘i (likely “Chief’s descendant” or “chiefly boy”) here takes an aggressive stance, wielding a ko‘ilipi (machete), a tool sharpened for cutting and symbolic of power and punishment. His readiness to cut Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s head (po‘o) — the locus of identity and mana — is a direct threat of death and domination.  
  – Nāmakaokapāo‘o, who earlier destroyed sweet potato patches, remains unyielding, ignoring Puali‘i’s first verbal warning and inspiring fear in nearby children. The children’s flight highlights the threat’s severity and adds a communal dimension to the scene, marking it as a moment of social tension.  
  – The specific action of “kunu” (piercing or skewering) four sweet potato vines atop the fire likely carries layered metaphorical meaning, involving destruction, sustenance, and a kind of ritual transformation (roasting the ‘uala vines and tubers).

• **Symbolism of the weapons and food:**  
  – The ko‘ilipi’s use is illustrative beyond the practical: as a cutting tool, it symbolizes finality, decisiveness, and the wielding of authority, particularly in conflicts involving chiefly rank or spiritual power.  
  – Puali‘i’s declaration that he will first eat Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s head cooked with sweet potatoes (‘uala) allegorizes a dominant ‘consuming’ over the younger figure, inverting normal kinship protection and signaling a breakdown of harmony or expected interpersonal relations. Eating the head is metaphorically absorbing the person’s mana or identity, often considered a symbolic act of ultimate power over an adversary.

• **The death chant (pule make):**  
  – Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s pule make is rich with cultural and linguistic references:  
    * “The eye of my head is only beloved” (Aloha wale ka maka o a‘u wahi pāo‘o): The ‘eye of the head’ is a poetic kenning referring to the essential, most beloved part of oneself — the head (po‘o) and its eyes (maka).  
    * “It flinches, it trembles” (E hapupu‘u, e hāpāpa‘a mai nei): Indicates vulnerability yet resilience or movement, a tension between fragility and resistance.  
    * “Should it eat, or should it allow” (E ‘ai paha, e waiho paha): Reflects a duality — whether to ‘consume’ or to ‘spare’— introducing ambiguity in fate and power relations.  
    * “Allow Nākukui‘aimakaokalani” (E waiho paha Nākukui‘aimakaokalani): Nākukui‘aimakaokalani is a highly significant name. Breaking it down:  
      – Nā-kukui – “the lights” or “candlenuts” (kukui nuts used for light), symbolizing enlightenment or guidance;  
      – ‘ai – “to eat” or “to use”;  
      – makaokalani – “eyes of the heavens” or “heavenly eyes” (“maka o ka lani”), invoking divine vision or protection.  
    This personal or ancestral name functions as a protective spirit or beloved companion invoked as a guardian or interceder.  
    * “That is Kukui‘aimakaokalani, this is my close companion,” reinforces the connection between the poem-speaker and this protective force.  
    * “Nāmakaokai‘a is the great chief of Hawai‘i,” introduces another prominent name:   
      – Nāmakaokai‘a (“eyes that consume the sea” or “sea-eating eyes”) suggests a powerful chiefly or divine being associated with the ocean’s expanse and strength. This may be a symbolic ancestor or a spiritual protector invoked in the prayer.  
    * “Let it glide, let the sting glide,” may allegorize the movement of spears or mana penetrating the enemy.  
    * “People with spears, the spear with the club,” conjures traditional Hawaiian weapons of war, referencing physical and metaphorical battle, enhancing the lethal seriousness of the conflict.  
    * The closing line, “Nāmakaokapāo‘o will truly die,” accepts the possibility of death but juxtaposes it with defiant invocation and honor, indicating that even in death, there is mana and spiritual presence.

• **Cultural and symbolic implications:**  
  – The exchange embodies a metaphorical struggle between tradition and innovation, or elder authority and younger challenge. Puali‘i represents enforcement of established hierarchical order with threat of death and consumption of the rival’s essence.  
  – Nāmakaokapāo‘o counters not by submission but through sacred invocation, reinforcing his spiritual identity and connection to divine and chiefly ancestors through named protective figures. This reflects Hawaiian values of mana, connection to lineage, and the power of ritual speech (pule) in confronting mortal danger.  
  – The fact that Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s pule make is uttered exactly when Puali‘i is about to strike suggests the protective power of prayer and the liminal space between life and death underscored by spiritual agency.  
  – The use of four sweet potato vines (‘ehā) resonates with the earlier paragraph’s numeric motif involving 2, 4, 40, suggesting ritual numerology and coded meaning tied to cultivation, sustenance, and renewal, juxtaposed against the threat of destruction.

• **Linguistic notes:**  
  – The use of “‘E!” as an exclamation to get attention conveys Puali‘i’s aggressive tone.  
  – “Noa” in “then you will be free” or “then you may be free” carries layered meaning: it can mean “free” in opposition to “kapu,” implying liberation in death or absolution from suffering.

• **Overall allegorical interpretation:**  
  – This passage dramatizes the tension between destruction and preservation, physical violence and spiritual protection, asserting the enduring authority of ancestral and divine guardians despite mortal peril. Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s prayer situates him within a cosmological framework where death is not simply an end but a transformation mediated by mana and lineage.  
  – Puali‘i’s threat to consume Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s head symbolically portrays power struggles over identity and mana, consistent with Hawaiian narratives where the ‘head’ is the seat of vital force.  
  – The invocation of named protective figures and chiefs within the pule make weaves individual fate into communal and cosmic orders, reflecting core Hawaiian worldviews about the interconnectedness of personal, genealogical, and spiritual realms.

In sum, this paragraph is a poignant nexus of physical threat, ritual response, and the assertion of identity through speech, deeply rooted in Hawaiian cultural concepts of mana, genealogy, and the sacred relationship between humans and the spirit world.

Puali‘i grabbed the machete and went until he reached where Nāmakaokapāo‘o was piercing four sweet potato vines over the fire. All the children saw and ran away, stopping in a distant place because they were afraid of Puali‘i. Puali‘i said to Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “Hey! Here is the machete in my hand, a tool to cut your head today, then your head will be cooked with the sweet potatoes, and I will eat first, then you will be free.” Nāmakaokapāo‘o did not listen to these words of Puali‘i, so Puali‘i spoke a second time. Puali‘i was ready to cut Nāmakaokapāo‘o with the machete when at that moment Nāmakaokapāo‘o prayed his death chant for Puali‘i. It went as follows:  
The eye of my head is only beloved,  
It flinches, it trembles,  
Should it eat, or should it allow,  
Allow Nākukui‘aimakaokalani,  
That is Kukui‘aimakaokalani,  
This is my close companion,  
Nāmakaokai‘a is the great chief of Hawai‘i,  
Let it glide, let the sting glide,  
People with spears,  
The spear with the club,  
Nāmakaokapāo‘o will truly die.
</translation>

<commentary>
• **Contextual overview:**  
  – This paragraph portrays a dramatic confrontation between Puali‘i and Nāmakaokapāo‘o amid a tense, symbolic scene involving sweet potato vines and a threatening machete. Puali‘i’s threat to sever Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s head is provocative and evokes themes of mortal conflict and ritual death, while Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s prayer or chant responds with a mix of defiance and invocation of ancestral and divine power.

• **Characters and actions:**

His readiness to cut Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s head (po‘o) — the locus of identity and mana — is a direct threat of death and domination.

The children’s flight highlights the threat’s severity and adds a communal dimension to the scene, marking it as a moment of social tension.

• **Symbolism of the weapons and food:**

  – Puali‘i’s declaration that he will first eat Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s head cooked with sweet potatoes (‘uala) allegorizes a dominant ‘consuming’ over the younger figure, inverting normal kinship protection and signaling a breakdown of harmony or expected interpersonal relations. Eating the head is metaphorically absorbing the person’s mana or identity, often considered a symbolic act of ultimate power over an adversary.

• **The death chant (pule make):**  
  – Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s pule make is rich with cultural and linguistic references:  
    * “The eye of my head is only beloved” (Aloha wale ka maka o a‘u wahi pāo‘o): The ‘eye of the head’ is a poetic kenning referring to the essential, most beloved part of oneself — the head (po‘o) and its eyes (maka).  
    * “It flinches, it trembles” (E hapupu‘u, e hāpāpa‘a mai nei): Indicates vulnerability yet resilience or movement, a tension between fragility and resistance.  
    * “Should it eat, or should it allow” (E ‘ai paha, e waiho paha): Reflects a duality — whether to ‘consume’ or to ‘spare’— introducing ambiguity in fate and power relations.  
    * “Allow Nākukui‘aimakaokalani” (E waiho paha Nākukui‘aimakaokalani): Nākukui‘aimakaokalani is a highly significant name. Breaking it down:  
      – Nā-kukui – “the lights” or “candlenuts” (kukui nuts used for light), symbolizing enlightenment or guidance;  
      – ‘ai – “to eat” or “to use”;  
      – makaokalani – “eyes of the heavens” or “heavenly eyes” (“maka o ka lani”), invoking divine vision or protection.  
    This personal or ancestral name functions as a protective spirit or beloved companion invoked as a guardian or interceder.  
    * “That is Kukui‘aimakaokalani, this is my close companion,” reinforces the connection between the poem-speaker and this protective force.  
    * “Nāmakaokai‘a is the great chief of Hawai‘i,” introduces another prominent name:   
      – Nāmakaokai‘a (“eyes that consume the sea” or “sea-eating eyes”) suggests a powerful chiefly or divine being associated with the ocean’s expanse and strength. This may be a symbolic ancestor or a spiritual protector invoked in the prayer.  
    * “Let it glide, let the sting glide,” may allegorize the movement of spears or mana penetrating the enemy.  
    * “People with spears, the spear with the club,” conjures traditional Hawaiian weapons of war, referencing physical and metaphorical battle, enhancing the lethal seriousness of the conflict.  
    * The closing line, “Nāmakaokapāo‘o will truly die,” accepts the possibility of death but juxtaposes it with defiant invocation and honor, indicating that even in death, there is mana and spiritual presence.

• **Cultural and symbolic implications:**  
  – The exchange embodies a metaphorical struggle between tradition and innovation, or elder authority and younger challenge. Puali‘i represents enforcement of established hierarchical order with threat of death and consumption of the rival’s essence.  
  – Nāmakaokapāo‘o counters not by submission but through sacred invocation, reinforcing his spiritual identity and connection to divine and chiefly ancestors through named protective figures. This reflects Hawaiian values of mana, connection to lineage, and the power of ritual speech (pule) in confronting mortal danger.  
  – The fact that Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s pule make is uttered exactly when Puali‘i is about to strike suggests the protective power of prayer and the liminal space between life and death underscored by spiritual agency.  
  – The use of four sweet potato vines (‘ehā) resonates with the earlier paragraph’s numeric motif involving 2, 4, 40, suggesting ritual numerology and coded meaning tied to cultivation, sustenance, and renewal, juxtaposed against the threat of destruction.

• **Linguistic notes:**  
  – The use of “‘E!” as an exclamation to get attention conveys Puali‘i’s aggressive tone.  
  – “Noa” in “then you will be free” or “then you may be free” carries layered meaning: it can mean “free” in opposition to “kapu,” implying liberation in death or absolution from suffering.

• **Overall allegorical interpretation:**  
  – This passage dramatizes the tension between destruction and preservation, physical violence and spiritual protection, asserting the enduring authority of ancestral and divine guardians despite mortal peril. Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s prayer situates him within a cosmological framework where death is not simply an end but a transformation mediated by mana and lineage.  
  – Puali‘i’s threat to consume Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s head symbolically portrays power struggles over identity and mana, consistent with Hawaiian narratives where the ‘head’ is the seat of vital force.  
  – The invocation of named protective figures and chiefs within the pule make weaves individual fate into communal and cosmic orders, reflecting core Hawaiian worldviews about the interconnectedness of personal, genealogical, and spiritual realms.

In sum, this paragraph is a poignant nexus of physical threat, ritual response, and the assertion of identity through speech, deeply rooted in Hawaiian cultural concepts of mana, genealogy, and the sacred relationship between humans and the spirit world.
</commentary>
reference_translation: Puali‘i grabbed and adze and went out to the  middle of the patches and found Nāmakaokapāo‘o  cooking four sweet potato vines on the fire. All the  children saw this and ran off and stood a long  distance away since they were so afraid of Puali‘i.  Puali‘i said to Nāmakaokapāo‘o, “Hey\! I got an  adze in my hand to cut off your head today. When  I cut your head off, I’ll cook it in the imu with  sweet potatoes and I’ll eat first, and then, it’ll be  free for others.” Nāmakaokapāo‘o paid no  attention to what Puali‘i said and Puali‘i said it  again. Puali‘i got ready to strike Nāmakaokapāo‘o  with the adze, and at that time, Nāmakaokapāo‘o  prayed a prayer of death of Puali‘i. This is what he  prayed:  How sad for the eyes of my precious pāo‘o fish Heaped up and burnt Should I eat it or leave it aside?  Maybe I should leave Nākukui‘aimakaokalani  alone  It is Kukui‘aimakaokalani afterall  My good friend.  Nāmakaokai‘a is the great chief of Hawai‘i Escaping, the coward escapes  The men with spears  Spears and drums  Killed by Nāmakaokapāo‘o
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 7:**• Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o was in the process of cooking 4  sweet potato vines after destroying the sweet potato  garden. It could be that the 4 vines represent the 4  primary gods of the Hawaiian people: Kāne, Kanaloa,  Kū, and Lono. Sweet potato was one of the most  important food crops that sustained the people (represented in this story by sweet potato and ulua  fish), along with taro (another representation of  humans), and this symbolically could represent the  only esoteric epistemology and lifestyle the Hawaiian  people ever knew in the ‘Ai Kapu era. Cooking the  vine and leaves renders the vegetable edible, while  also killing it, a type of ritual canibalism.  • The words of the prayer offered in chant form  (prosidy) are a type of lament by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o  for Pua-li‘i (i.e. pitying him) and a prediction that Pua li‘i would die a gruesome death despite the fact that  Pua-li‘i was the one about to attack Nā-maka-o-ka pāo‘o with an adze. The prayer essentially says that  enlightenment would consume the eater of the flesh  of men and that the customs of war and hula (i.e.  ʻpahu’) would retreat like cowards, having been killed  off by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o. This is likely a reference  to Christian ʻenlightenment’ replacing the ‘Ai Kapu  across the Hawaiian Islands.
